[Please replace "invertible functor" with "equivalence" in your reading of this question, if it would make the question more interesting to you.]

Let C\mathsf{C}C be a category. For any morphisms a,ba,ba,b in C\mathsf{C}C, let a∼ba \sim ba∼b if there exists an invertible functor F:C→CF: \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{C}F:C→C so that F(a)=bF(a) = bF(a)=b.

I think ∼\sim∼ is an equivalence relationship:
I know that the identity functor Id:C→CId: \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{C}Id:C→C is an invertible functor, acting as its own inverse. So a∼aa \sim aa∼a.

If F:C→CF:\mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{C}F:C→C is an invertible functor, then its inverse GGG is as well. If a∼ba \sim ba∼b, then F(a)=bF(a) = bF(a)=b, so G(F(a))=G(b)G(F(a)) = G(b)G(F(a))=G(b) and so G(b)=aG(b) = aG(b)=a. That means b∼ab \sim ab∼a if a∼ba \sim ba∼b.

If a∼ba \sim ba∼b and b∼cb \sim cb∼c, then F(a)=bF(a) = bF(a)=b and H(b)=cH(b) = cH(b)=c for invertible functors F,H:C→CF,H: \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{C}F,H:C→C. Composing these two to get another invertible functor, we find (H∘F)(a)=H(F(a))=H(b)=c(H \circ F)(a) = H(F(a)) = H(b) = c(H∘F)(a)=H(F(a))=H(b)=c and so a∼ca \sim ca∼c.

If there is a standard name for this equivalence relationship, I'd be interested to learn it! I'm also interested in any examples of the resulting equivalence classes in different categories. For example, I think conjugacy classes in a group are one interesting example of equivalence classes generated in this way!
This is a very nice question, but please replace "invertible functor" with "equivalence" if you want good answers. An equivalence of categories is a functor that invertible up to natural isomorphism.
Isomorphisms of categories are too brittle to be useful: equivalences do what you really want.
All the stuff you said would work for equivalences.

For example, I think conjugacy classes in a group are one interesting example of equivalence classes generated in this way!

How do you want to think about that? You can think of group elements as morphisms in the one-object category corresponding to that group.
But you seem to be wanting to think of them as objects in some category.

John Baez said:

This is a very nice question, but please replace "invertible functor" with "equivalence" if you want good answers. An equivalence of categories is a functor that invertible up to natural isomorphism.

I see! Unfortunately I'm out of steam for today to edit my question right now. But I would be very happy to instead consider the improved version of the question with "equivalence" replacing "invertible functor".

John Baez said:

For example, I think conjugacy classes in a group are one interesting example of equivalence classes generated in this way!

How do you want to think about that? You can think of group elements as morphisms in the one-object category corresponding to that group.

I was thinking of a group as an object with a single category, and with all morphisms isomorphisms. Then we have an invertible functor from the group back to itself provided by conjugation with any element. This induces an equivalence relationship on the morphisms of this category as described above, I believe.

Oh, yes it does. For some reason I automatically assumed you were going to put an equivalence relation on objects of the category C\mathsf{C}C such that a∼b a \sim ba∼b iff there's some equivalence F:C→CF: \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{C}F:C→C such that F(a)=bF(a) = bF(a)=b.
You can also do that.

And by the way, if we use equivalences F:C→CF : \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{C}F:C→C, then the equivalence relation I just mentioned is the same as this morally superior one: a∼b a \sim ba∼b iff there's some equivalence F:C→CF: \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{C}F:C→C such that F(a)≅bF(a) \cong bF(a)≅b.

The reason is that you can tweak an equivalence, getting a new equivalence where F(a)F(a)F(a) is changed to any other isomorphic object! So if you had F(a)≃bF(a) \simeq bF(a)≃b you can change FFF to a new equivalence F′F'F′ with F(a)=bF(a) = bF(a)=b.
You can't do this with isomorphisms: that's an example of how they are "brittle".
But anyway, okay, so you were putting an equivalence relation on morphisms. You can do that too.
So then the good news is: conjugate elements of a group will indeed give equivalent morphisms in your sense.
And the bad news is: group elements don't need to be conjugate to be equivalent in your sense.
It's not really "bad" news - it's just true news, nothing in math is bad. I've just heard too many "good news, bad news" jokes. :upside_down:

So just for fun:

Puzzle: in the group Z/4\mathbb{Z}/4Z/4, thought of as a 1-object category, find two elements that are equivalent in your sense but not conjugate.

And I'll say that in this puzzle it doesn't matter whether you use isomorphisms of categories, as you originally wanted to, or equivalences of categories. So you can use isomorphisms; they're a bit simpler.

John Baez said:

So just for fun:

Puzzle: in the group Z/4\mathbb{Z}/4Z/4, thought of as a 1-object category, find two elements that are equivalent in your sense but not conjugate.

I remember seeing that the group of integers together with addition has an automorphism corresponding to negation. So, in the sense described above, we have a∼−aa \sim -aa∼−a for each integer aaa in Z\mathbb{Z}Z.

Maybe this works for the group Z/4\mathbb{Z}/4Z/4 too (which I assume is the group of integers modulo 4 together with addition)? Now, Z/4\mathbb{Z}/4Z/4 becomes a ring when we add in multiplication modulo 4, and the equivalence class of the integers in Z/4\mathbb{Z}/4Z/4 containing -1 is 3. So, I'm wondering if multiplying by 3 (modulo 4) is an automorphism of Z/4\mathbb{Z}/4Z/4. Since 3 is relatively prime to 4, this map should be injective and hence (in this case) surjective. According to google, ring bijections are ring isomorphisms, and so multiplying by 3 (modulo 4) should in particular be a group isomorphism.
So, "negating" our elements (multiplying by 3, modulo 4) is a group automorphism and acts on elements as follows:

  • 0↦00 \mapsto 00↦0
  • 1↦31 \mapsto 31↦3
  • 2↦22 \mapsto 22↦2
  • 3↦1 3 \mapsto 13↦1
    In the sense described above, that means we again we have a∼−aa \sim -aa∼−a for each a∈Z/4a \in \mathbb{Z}/4a∈Z/4. So, 0∼00 \sim 00∼0, 1∼31 \sim 31∼3, and 2∼22 \sim 22∼2.

This group is commutative, so any two distinct elements are not conjugate. So, 1∼31 \sim 31∼3 even though 1 and 3 are not conjugate.

John Baez said:

It's not really "bad" news - it's just true news, nothing in math is bad. I've just heard too many "good news, bad news" jokes. :upside_down:

Yes, I find it fun that this construction does something a bit different than relating conjugating elements!
Yes, you got it! The group Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 also has this property, that there are "equivalent" elements that are non-conjugate.
I guess every finite abelian group has this property except Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2.

In the language of group theory, what we're talking about is related to the difference between an automorphism of a group GGG, which is an invertible map f:G→Gf : G \to Gf:G→G that preserves multiplication (and thus the identity and inverses too), and an [[inner automorphism]], which is an automorphism of the form

f(g)=hgh−1f(g) = hgh^{-1}f(g)=hgh−1
Two group elements are "equivalent" in your sense iff there's an automorphism mapping the first to the second.
Two group elements are conjugate iff there's an inner automorphism mapping the first two the second.

Abelian groups never have any inner automorphisms except the identity, but they often have lots of automorphisms, and they always have the automorphism

f(g)=g−1f(g) = g^{-1}f(g)=g−1

which is the one you wound up using to solve the puzzle.
(But you wrote it as f(g)=−gf(g) = -gf(g)=−g since you were using additive notation, as people often do for abelian groups.)
There's a lot to say about the distinction between the looser concept of "equivalent" and the stricter concept of "conjugate" - it's a really interesting issue.
Some of this stuff is stuff group theorists talk about, and some is stuff category theorists are more likely to talk about.

For fun, I think here are two more examples of things that are related in the sense described above:

  • Any two identity morphisms (or objects) in a discrete category
  • fff and ggg (or aaa and bbb) in this little category:

a little category
Yes, basically you've given a condition under which two morphisms are "indistinguishable unless we attach arbitrary names to the objects or morphisms in the category".

Before I forget to do it, let me say the nice category-theoretic way to distinguish:

1) an element ggg of a group GGG that's mapped to an element g′g'g′ by some automorphism: f(g)=g′f(g) = g'f(g)=g′

from

2) an element ggg of a group GGG that's mapped to an element g′g'g′ by some inner automorphism: hgh−1=g′hgh^{-1} = g'hgh−1=g′
The group elements ggg and g′g'g′ are "more alike" in the second case than in the first case, but what do we mean by that?
Think of a group as a 1-object category and think of its elements as morphisms.
Then case 1) happens iff there's an equivalence of categories mapping ggg to g′g'g′.
But case 2) happens iff there's an equivalence of categories that's naturally isomorphic to the identity mapping ggg to g′g'g′.
I love this. Not only is g′g'g′ a lot like ggg, but the way they're alike is a lot like the identity.
That is very cool indeed! I love how category theory nicely provides a variety of levels of the concept of "same-ness".

Yes, it's great!

I think a nice example is the group of symmetries of a square (the dihedral group D4D_4D4​). The reflection that switches the top and bottom edges is a lot like a reflection that switches two opposite corners. But I think it's more like the reflection that switches the left and right edges.

If I'm not confused, the first pair of symmetries are related by an an automorphism of the group, while the second pair are related by an inner automorphism - an equivalence that's naturally isomorphic to the identity.

That example reminds me of some of the patterns used to solve the 3x3x3 Rubik's cube! It's common to "get pieces into position, do something, and then return pieces back", which follows the form hgh−1hgh^{-1}hgh−1.

Yes! In fact I've seen a whole book about how conjugation is used to solve problems. For example: if you drop a ball on the other side of the fence but can't reach it, you walk down the fence to a gate, go through the gate, then walk back along the fence to your ball.
These "conjugations" are, in some perhaps vague sense, example of natural isomorphisms.
I wish I could remember the name of that book!
